title: Radical Reconstruction
subtitle: Congressional Control (1867-1870)
narrator: Eliza, age 16, freed slave in South Carolina, 1868

sections.title: Congress Takes Control
sections.summary: I'm Eliza, sixteen years old, and I live in South Carolina. I was born enslaved but freed when I was thirteen, after the Civil War ended. The past three years have been chaotic—freedom without resources, Black Codes restricting our rights, President Johnson allowing former Confederates back into pow...

sections.title: Constitutional Conventions
sections.summary: Early 1868. South Carolina holds a constitutional convention to write a new state constitution. For the first time, Black men participate in government.

sections.title: The Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments
sections.summary: The constitutional changes aren't just at the state level. Congress is rewriting the U.S. Constitution to protect Black rights.

sections.title: Progress and Achievement
sections.summary: The years 1868-1870 are a time of remarkable progress in South Carolina. Black men serve in the legislature, as sheriffs and judges, as members of Congress. Hiram Revels of Mississippi becomes the first Black U.S.

sections.title: The Reign of Terror
sections.summary: But white conservatives won't accept this new order. They use violence to restore white supremacy and undo Reconstruction. The Ku Klux Klan—a terrorist organization of former Confederates—spreads across the South.

vocabulary.definition: Congressional plan (1867-1877) imposing harsh terms on South and protecting Black rights.
1868 amendment granting citizenship and equal protection to freed slaves.
1870 amendment protecting voting rights regardless of race.
Laws placing South under military control until new constitutions guaranteeing Black voting rights.
Terrorist organization using violence to restore white supremacy and intimidate Black voters.
First Black U.S. Senator, representing Mississippi during Reconstruction.
